executive_summary: The Engine Rebuilding and Remanufacturing industry tends to run counter to typically positive economic indicators. When consumer income levels are high, demand tends to fall because consumers favor new car purchases over rebuilt or remanufactured engines. Over the five years to 2019, rising disposable income levels and improved consumer confidence have supported new car purchases, which has stifled industry demand. In contrast, rebounding industrial and heavy manufacturing activity over the past five years has helped boost demand for remanufactured diesel engines from heavy industrial and construction customers.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The industry functions countercyclically to typical auto parts manufacturing industries. Demand is related to per capita disposable income and the economic climate surrounding US auto markets.
Industry revenue is expected to decline at an annualized rate of 1.3% to $2.2 billion over the five years to 2019, despite projected 1.4% increase in 2019.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Industry revenue is projected to grow at an annualized rate of 0.7% over the five years to 2024 to $2.3 billion.
Advanced engines will increase manufacturers' capital requirements and limit profit margin, which is anticipated to generate consolidation.

industry_definition: Companies in this industry primarily rebuild and remanufacture automotive engines and engine parts for motor vehicles. Remanufacturing is the process of returning a used, worn-out engine to as close to new as possible, whereas rebuilding generally describes a process that makes greater use of serviceable parts rather than new ones. Recycling, repairs and restorations are excluded from the industry.

opportunities: High Performance Drivers - Per capita disposable income

key_trends: Revenue tends to move countercyclical to the economy at large
New car sales have increased, driving down consumer demand for industry services
Demand from industrial markets has remained strong
Strong sales of hybrid vehicles will present greater technical and operational challenges
Rising disposable income levels are expected to support purchases by US consumers
Increased price-based competition and purchase costs will inhibit profitability
Countervailing pressures are projected to limit industry revenue growth over the next five years

market_segmentation.segment_description: Demand from commercial fleet maintenance providers is expected to generate 14.2% of the industry's revenue in 2019. These fleets include industrial, general manufacturing and transportation fleets.

Demand from consumers and auto mechanics is expected to generate a combined 58.4% of industry revenue in 2019. Within this segment, direct sales to consumers account for an estimated 45.8% of revenue, while sales to auto mechanics account for the remaining 12.6% share.

An expected 13.7% of industry revenue is accounted for by dealerships and distributors. Dealerships primarily demand remanufactured engines as part of used car sales and repair services offered to consumers under warranty. Distributors act as an intermediary market for remanufactured engines.
The other markets are primarily accounted for by other equipment manufacturers. Industry operators also produce remanufactured or rebuilt engine parts.

products_and_services.product_description: The sale of rebuilt or remanufactured heavy-duty diesel engines is expected to account for 25.5% of industry revenue in 2019.
Gasoline automotive engines are expected to account for 50.5% of industry revenue.
Diesel automotive remanufactured engines are expected to account for 14.5% of revenue.
The industry also rebuilds and remanufactures various other types of engines. These are almost exclusive to industrial machinery, which uses liquefied petroleum gas or other fuel sources.

tier_2_suppliers: Gasoline & Petroleum Wholesaling in the US
Recyclable Material Wholesaling in the US
tier_1_buyers: Transportation and Warehousing in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: As disposable income rises, consumers are more likely to spend on repairs for their vehicles. However, rapid rises in disposable income may entice consumers to purchase new vehicles rather than repair existing ones.
Rises in corporate profit improve downstream operators' ability to pay for engine repair costs, although surges in downstream corporate profit may result in the purchase of new vehicles.

Legislation can affect demand for industry products as well. Depending on regulation, business owners who own fleets or single vehicles may have to upgrade existing engines (increasing industry demand) or purchase new vehicles altogether (decreasing industry demand).

Consumer preferences for various car qualities tend to increase automotive complexity. As cars become more complex this increases the price and remanufactured engines, which become more expensive to produce.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Operators in the industry do not directly import and export merchandise; rather, they stock items that have been sourced from international locations.
Regulation and policy changes affecting international trade, including tariff legislation, affects the price upstream suppliers are charged.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region has the highest number of establishments, accounting for 22.6% of the total, which is slightly lower than the region's share of the US population and the proportion of passenger vehicles in use.
The Mid-Atlantic region has the second-highest portion of industry establishments, accounting for 17.2%.

The West region has the third-highest portion of industry establishments, accounting for 16.3%. While an estimated 17.0% of the US population lives in the West, the region has almost one-fifth of passenger vehicles.

regulations_points.regulation_description: There are no major government regulations on the Engine Rebuilding and Remanufacturing industry. However, there are codes of practice that affect this industry.
The policy ensures that products meet reasonable performance requirements and that are composed of the highest percentage of recovered materials practicable.

barriers_points.barrier_title: Engine rebuilding has relatively low barriers
barriers_points.barrier_description: The engine rebuilding segment has maintained relatively low barriers to entry during the past five years since engine rebuilders are primarily small, independent ventures operating as stand-alone enterprises or as a part of a larger automotive services garage.

barriers_points.barrier_title: Engine remanufacturing has higher barriers due to capital requirements
barriers_points.barrier_description: Meanwhile, the engine remanufacturing segment has relatively higher barriers to entry, due to greater capital investment requirements.

basis_points.basis_title: Basis of competition includes price, product availability, reputation, turnaround time and value-added services
basis_points.basis_description: The Engine Rebuilding and Remanufacturing industry features a moderate level of competition, with operators competing primarily on the basis of price, product availability, reputation, turnaround time and the provision of value-added services such as extended warranties and installation.

basis_points.basis_title: Highly specialized process requiring skilled labor and capital investments
basis_points.basis_description: Engine rebuilding and remanufacturing is a highly specialized process demanding skilled labor and specific types of capital investments into tools, machinery, parts and raw materials.

basis_points.basis_title: Few alternatives besides outright vehicle replacement
basis_points.basis_description: As such, there are few alternatives besides outright vehicle replacement, thus reducing competition from substitutes.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Top 4 operators account for 31.7% of revenue in 2019
concentration_points.concentration_description: The Engine Rebuilding and Remanufacturing industry has a low level of market share concentration, with the four largest operators expected to account for 31.7% of 2019 industry revenue.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Majority are small, specialized auto repair shops
concentration_points.concentration_description: Companies known as engine rebuilders constitute the majority of small enterprises in this industry, most of which operate as specialized auto repair shops that serve smaller geographic markets.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Remanufacturers are typically larger due to higher barriers
concentration_points.concentration_description: Engine remanufacturers are typically larger in scope since these companies face significantly higher barriers to entry and success than rebuilders.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Concentration has increased due to exits and M&A activity
concentration_points.concentration_description: However, market share concentration has increased significantly over the past five years as underperforming companies exited the market due to weakened demand for remanufacturing and rising barriers to success.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wages are estimated to account for 16.5% of revenue in 2019. Engine rebuilding and remanufacturing is relatively labor intensive, and skilled workers are required to disassemble and reassemble engine systems, match them with their factory-rated tolerances, replace any worn parts and perform final inspections.
As with many manufacturing industries, purchases constitute the largest cost segment for the average operator. In this industry, purchases are expected to be 67.6% of revenue.
Profit, measured as earnings before interest and taxes, is expected to decline to 6.3% of revenue over the five years to 2019 from 8.0% in 2014.
Operators across all product segments must invest in workshops, machine tools and other machinery.
Administration, repair and maintenance, communications and other miscellaneous expenses are estimated to account for 6.3% of revenue.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Engine rebuilding and remanufacturing is a labor-intensive process. The efficiency with which labor is employed has a major influence on output.
Facilities used by the Engine Rebuilding and Remanufacturing industry typically have long economic life.

volatility_points.volatility_description: The Engine Rebuilding and Remanufacturing industry is sensitive to changes in business cycles and household income, because industry products tend to be more cost effective than replacing existing vehicles.
As a result, revenue growth has been volatile over the past five years, reflecting macroeconomic conditions.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The technology used by the Engine Rebuilding and Remanufacturing industry relates to machinery and materials used.
While there is little technological change in the equipment used in the rebuild and remanufacture engines, the rate of technological change in the varying parts required is more rapid.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: In an inverse way: Demand for the industry's services from consumers actually increases if disposable income fall.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in a niche or do you produce a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: Smaller companies in the industry tend to be specialized in a particular type of engine to remanufacture, while major players tend offer services on multiple engine types.

FAQs.question: Has your company located near key downstream customers to reduce shipping costs?
FAQs.answer: Some companies in this industry do locate themselves near strategic large customers in order reduce shipping costs.

FAQs.question: How often does your company purchase new equipment?
FAQs.answer: More companies in the industry are having to purchase more specialized equipment in order to remanufacture the technically complex engines of today.

FAQs.question: How has input price volatility affected profit margins over the past 12 months?
FAQs.answer: Profits have been dampened by increasing component cost as well higher prices for used engine blocks.
